channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Deadly Landslide Hits Central Sri Lanka
item.description: At least six people were killed and around 300 were missing after an early morning landslide set off by heavy monsoon rains.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Michael Sata, Sharp-Tongued President of Zambia, Dies at 77
item.description: The cause of Mr. Sata’s death, after months of largely unchronicled illness, was not made public.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Michael Sata, the president of Zambia, reviewed an honor guard in Lusaka in September.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Pankaj Mishra on the Hong Kong Protests
item.description: The author shares his thoughts on capitalism and politics in China, and on Hong Kong’s relationship to the mainland.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: The author Pankaj Mishra has traveled to far-flung parts of Asia for his reporting.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Modern Slavery in Bangladesh
item.description: Although many people in Bangladesh would deny it, we practice our own form of slavery.
item.dc:creator: By LIPIKA PELHAM

item.title: Letter From the Middle East: For Israelis and Palestinians, Another Divide to Contend With: Time
item.description: After decades of fighting over borders and refugees, Israelis and Palestinians cannot even agree on what time it is, as their daylight saving calendars remain out of sync.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Taking Back Hong Kong's Future
item.description: The young protesters want what everybody else in an advanced society seems to have: a say in how we are governed.
item.dc:creator: By JOSHUA WONG CHI-FUNG

item.title: Politician Who Called for Hong Kong Leader’s Resignation Is Formally Penalized
item.description: James Tien, the head of Hong Kong’s pro-business Liberal Party, was removed from a largely powerless but prestigious organ of China’s government.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: James Tien, a pro-Beijing lawmaker, had called for Hong Kong’s leader to resign.

item.title: Indictment on Terrorism Charge Traces Man’s Arc From Germany to Syria and Back
item.description: A document provides an unusually detailed account of how Ismail Issa, 24, ended up under arrest on suspicion of supporting jihadists.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Backing Protests, Chow Yun-fat Shrugs Off Risk to Career
item.description: Amid pressure from the Communist Party in Beijing to drop their support for Hong Kong democracy protests, some Hong Kong stars in the city have spoken out — and others are cowed. One, Chow Yun-fat, appears nonchalant.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Zambian President Dies in London Hospital
item.description: Zambian leader Michael Sata, a longtime opposition leader who was finally elected president in 2011, died after an illness, the Zambian government said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Michael Sata, the president of Zambia, reviewed an honor guard in Lusaka in September.

item.title: Lens Blog: Poverty and Uncertainty for Widows of Syrian ‘Freedom Fighters’
item.description: Their husbands died fighting the Syrian government. Today, their widows who have been given safe haven in Jordan lead impoverished, vulnerable lives.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: Two sisters posing for a portrait in their living room in a "Martyrs' Wives" building. They are young enough to go to school and are still allowed to go outside. Once they get older, they will more than likely spend their days inside the apartment and possibly be pushed into an early marriage.

item.title: Theo Padnos, American Journalist, on Being Kidnapped, Tortured and Released in Syria
item.description: In 2012, Theo Padnos was kidnapped in Syria by the Nusra Front. After months of beatings and torture, he was certain he would be executed. Instead, he lived to tell this tale.
item.dc:creator: By THEO PADNOS
item.media:credit: Andrea Modica for The New York Times

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: 21 Arrested Over Deadly Land Clash in Southwest China
item.description: Those arrested included six employees of a construction firm and 15 residents of Jinning County, in the southwestern province of Yunnan, who participated in a clash over land development that left nine dead.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Villagers in Fuyou, Jinning County, displaying police shields and other equipment they confiscated after a clash with construction workers on Oct. 14.

item.title: Bangladesh Islamist Party Chief Sentenced to Death
item.description: A special tribunal in Bangladesh on Wednesday sentenced the leader of the country's largest Islamist party to death for his role in the deaths of thousands of people during the nation's independence war against Pakistan in 1971.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Liberia, a Good or Very Bad Sign: Empty Hospital Beds
item.description: Liberia has far fewer people being treated for Ebola than anticipated, but health officials are hesitant to declare victory.
item.dc:creator: By SHERI FINK
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ebola field hospital in Bong County, Liberia, which opened in mid-September, has far fewer patients than anticipated.

item.title: Egypt Orders Evacuation Along Gaza Border to Thwart Militants
item.description: Egyptian officials plan a buffer zone next to the Hamas-ruled territory, only days after an army post was attacked.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Shipping a Serious, but Overlooked, Source of China’s Pollution, Report Says
item.description: Container vessels use a cheap fuel that emits a dense trail of soot and helps cause the small-particle pollution that hangs over many Chinese cities, the Natural Resources Defense Council said.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: An employee viewing the Port of Shanghai, the world's busiest, from an office window.

item.title: U.S. Immigration Laws Face New Scrutiny After Killings
item.description: The case could create a new problem for the Obama administration, as officials weigh steps the president could take after the Nov. 4 elections to expand protections from deportation for immigrants here illegally.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER MEDINA and JULIA PRESTON
item.media:credit: Randall Benton/The Sacramento Bee, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Two sheriff’s officers were killed Friday in a shooting in California.

item.title: Computing the Political Impact of Canada’s Attacks
item.description: After two attacks by homegrown extremists, the questions now are about the impact on Prime Minister Stephen Harper’s future.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL WINES and IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Stephen Harper, center, after the funeral for Cpl. Nathan Cirillo on Tuesday.

item.title: In Mexico, a New Lead on Missing Students
item.description: Led to a dump near Cocula, the authorities seemed no closer to finding the 43 students who vanished after being arrested a month ago in Iguala.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS and ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Soldiers escorted a convoy carrying forensics experts to a mountainous area in the state of Guerrero.

item.title: U.N. Rights Investigator Says North Korea May Allow a Visit
item.description: The reported gesture came amid intrigue over the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, who South Korean intelligence officials said was recovering from surgery on his left foot.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Korea News Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The North Korean leader Kim Jong-un in Pyongyang, in an undated image released by the Korean Central News Agency.

item.title: Open Source: Echoes of Patty Hearst in Kobani
item.description: Narration by the British hostage John Cantlie on Islamic State propaganda videos is reminiscent of recordings by the kidnapped Patty Hearst.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screen shot from video recorded recently in Kobani, Syria, by Islamic State militants shows a distinctive silver silo topped by a Turkish flag near the border between Turkey and Syria.

item.title: World Briefing: Ecuador: Tortoise Species Is Saved
item.description: Conservationists said Tuesday that they had brought giant tortoises on the Galápagos island of Española back from the brink of extinction.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Arequipa Journal: Despite Rumors, Not Everything That Towers Is Eiffel’s
item.description: In parts of Peru and Chile, famed engineer Gustave Eiffel’s name is linked to many structures he had nothing to do with.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Iron Bridge in Arequipa, Peru.

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Deadly School Bus Crash
item.description: Eleven people, mostly teenagers, were killed when a truck loaded with vegetable oil collided head-on with a bus full of high school students in southeastern Brazil, near Ibitinga, the police said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
